""We are an open source, YCombinator backed startup (you can see our repo here [REDACTED_URL] looking to bring a full-stack engineer on to work primarily on our front end. Improve this resume bullet:
""Part IOverview:In the first part of the final project, you will set up a complex scene by loading from two simple file formats—OBJ models accompanied by MTL material files. You will then apply lighting and texturing. When it is done, your scene will consist of a lit and colored car sitting on a lit and colored road next to a lit and textured stop sign, illuminated by a lit and colored streetlamp.Part 1-1: Setting your SceneThe first step is to review the starter code for this project. It contains a Model and a Face class and a series of calls that take in OBJ and MTL files and parses them into Model objects. Make sure you understand what this code is doing and what it returns so that you know how to use it in your program. You are welcome (but not required) to make any modifications to this code that you see fit. If you see any errors in this starter code or have any suggestions for improvement, let the instructor know.The starter code produces several console.log() statements that allow you to look at everything that has been processed from the files. You should study these statements to understand how the data in the Model class is organized. In particular, node how Model has an array of Face instances that contain all of the vertices, normals, and texture coordinates for each face in that model. The faces have all been triangulated for you, so you can just pass them directly into the vertex shader (either one face at a time or all at once) to draw your mesh using gl.TRIANGLES. Each face also has a corresponding material field that references one of the materials in the diffuseMap and specularMap fields in Model. You can use this information to look up the appropriate values for your lighting calculations on that face.Once you are comfortable with the above information, you should then render your models in a simple view to verify that your program is working. (HINT: Start with the stop sign, since it's the simplest mesh.) You will then want to set up your scene as shown in the demo video (you will incorporate the bunny in a later step). Once everything is set up correctly, you should then turn your attention to the MTL files.Diffuse colors in the form “Kd [R] [G] [B]”Specular colors in the form “Ks [R] [G] [B]”A diffuse texture map in the form “map_Kd [Map Image]”Part 1-2: LightingNext, you will place a point light at the top of your streetlamp to illuminate your scene. Your light should use Phong shading, and you should use the previously loaded diffuse and specular material colors from the MTL file. You may create your own ambient color.Allow the user to press the ‘L’ key to toggle the light on/off, but make sure that ambient light is still applied to your scene even when the light is off.Implementation Notes:Your lighting will likely look flat simply due to the normals on the provided models not being smoothed.Part 1-3: TexturingNext, you will implement texturing in your program using the texture coordinates loaded from the stop sign’s OBJ file, accompanied by the stop.png texture as specified in the map_Kd attribute of the material in stopsign.mtl.Implementation Notes:The texture coordinates in the OBJ file are flipped along the Y-axis; to get your final texture coordinates, you should subtract the V coordinates from 1.Part 1-4: Camera AnimationFinally, you will implement basic camera animation so that the user can view your scene from different angles. When the user presses the ‘C’ key, make the camera move along a circle on the XZ plane, while bobbing up and down slightly (along the Y-axis) as shown in the demo. (HINT: Think about how you might use the trigonometric functions.) The camera should not jump at all when the user starts or stops the animation and should preserve its current state.Part IIFinal Project Part II DemoLinks in starter fileOverview:In the second part of the final project, you will use a matrix stack to structure your scene through hierarchical transformations. You will also implement simple shadows, reflections, and refractions.Part 2-1: Hierarchical TransformationsPart 2-2: Hierarchical CameraPart 2-3: ShadowsPart 2-4: SkyboxPart 2-5: Reflections and Refractions (i.e. Environment Maps)Make bids and I will share more details and files also in chats.Happy Bidding!!!Budget: $80Posted On: February 20, 2024 18:16 UTCCategory: Video Game DevelopmentSkills:TypeScript, JavaScriptSkills: TypeScript, JavaScriptCountry: India""

Return the exit code that the invoked program in #5 returned (or, if extraction failed for any reason, return a custom non-zero numeric failure code).Details for #3 above:a. The archive being extracted may be password protected. The program shall be sent all of the command line parameters that the self-extractor itself received while being launched.c. The program shall also be sent the full path to the self-extractor executable as part of the "/m" command line parameter, to be added to the existing command line it is being sent (if any).General Details:============i. The final binary must have no dependencies other than the existing dependencies already required by the current version of the p7zip project.ii. The final binary must be a command line only tool (no GUI whatsoever). Extraction progress (and any error messages) shall only be displayed on the command line. Any user input shall only be prompted on the command line.iii. The final binary must support 100% silent operation when the "/s" command line parameter is specified. It must complete all tasks absolutely silently and non-interactively (the invoked application itself may be non-silent, of course), with zero output to the command line while retaining 100% of the behavior above.iv. Support for any existing command line parameters available in SFXCon (which is similar to 7zip's own command line interface) are to be dropped.Schematic of a Built SFX:===================[your customized SFXCon binary] + [text file specifying name of program to launch] + [7zip archive to extract]You will use Linux system calls to determine the length of your compiled binary and start reading past it to locate the text file appended to it. ""Language translation is an art and science that aims to transfer meanings and concepts from one language to another accurately and faithfully. ""We are moving to 3CX Windows soft phone but we use software inside of an RDS environment, and the softphone must run on the client machine directly to make the audio work properly.We need some client/server middleware to assist with this.We want to run the softphone on the client machine but can interact with it from the RDS desktop. I don't need a GUI on the RDS desktop though.I have already using Auto Hotkey made a simple script as proof of concept which uses Winset "Always On Top" to make the 3cx GUI sit on top of the RDS session so the GUI can be used by the user---F12::WinRestore, 3CXWinGetTitle, title, Atitle = RegExReplace, title,#redacted this for upwork compatibility, removes invalid characters#If $titlenew = "3CX"Winset, AlwaysOnTop, On, A----This works, however F12 cant be captured on the Client machine when the RDS is active (have to press ctrl + alt + home first)I need call information from the softphone passing to the RDS session , and click to dial to work from the RDS SessionI want to build the app initially as this job, but there will be further functionality development for it in future.So here is how it should work::- Requirements - We need 2 Executables 1 which runs on the client machine, 1 that runs on the RDS. RDS has an environment variable I have setup "CLIENTIP" The RDS instance should setup a TCP connection (to a specific port so I can allow on firewalls) to the client executable so they can send each other date / commands. For the rest of this explanation, I will call them RDS.exe and CLIENT.exe RDS.exe should constantly check to see if the CLIENTIP environment variable has changed (if they have reconnected from a new device) and reestablish the TCP link if it has. If the link cannot be established then it should retry every ~ 10 seconds until it manages to establish.RDS.exe and Client.exe should run in the system tray with a green icon if the TCP connection is established, and a red icon if not, right clicking the icon should have the option to exit or restart, but no other GUI is needed at this stage.- Function 1 - Softphone Access in RDS - If the RDS.exe see's the user press F12, it should send a request to CLIENT.exe to Show/Hide the softphone. When CLIENT.EXE receives this request if softphone is currently open as a a window, then it should minimise it. If it is currently not open as a window it should check if it is running at all, and if not launch it. Then if minimised restore it, and use Winset, AlwaysOnTop to keep it above the RDS session display.So effectively when someone is in an RDS session they can press F12 to toggle the locally ran softphone displaying above their RDS session, or minimising out of the way.- Function 2 - Passing Caller ID - When the 3XC Softphone client on the client answers a call it can open a URL which contains the caller ID (“Settings - Integration - Open Custom URL” on the 3cx system) We need to associate the URL with CLIENT.exe so it sends the callerID here something like ACAMIDDLEWARE:[REDACTED_NUM] . When CLIENT.exe receives this URL it needs to send it to RDS.exe and RDS.exe needs to save it to a plain text file on the user profile %APPDATA%\ACAMIDDLEWARE\LastCallAnswered.txt (so that our CRM software can look at this when it needs to for integration reasons).We will add further functions utilising this in later versions, but for the initial development this is all it needs to do.- Function 3 - Click to dial from RDS - On the RDS I will associate Tel: to RDS.EXE , when someone clicks a tel: Link on the rds then RDS.exe should capture this and send it to CLIENT.exe which will execute the tel: Link and dial the number through the softphone which is running on the client.- Future work - In the future there will be more work where RDS.exe can SQL lookup the number sent to it from CLIENT.exe upon answering a call and display a ‘toast’ popup with relevant information and links in it on the RDS desktop. However I’m not too fussed about making this work on this initial job we can work on that for version 2. There will be further functionality added in future too.- Development Environment - I want this project built in the latest version of Visual Studio using c#, and I want all source code and project files supplied, we will still utilise you for all further development, but I am learning c# at the moment and want to be able to make small changes myself and understand how it works.Please provide a quote and timeframe, feel free to ask any questions.Posted On: February 23, 2024 14:19 UTCCategory: Tech SupportSkills:Windows App Development, C#Skills: Windows App Development, C#Country: United Kingdom""
